title: How to Recognize Symptoms of Cat Scratch Disease

steps.title: Check for redness and swelling.
steps.content: Check for redness and swelling. The first sign that a wound might be infected is redness and inflammation around the site of the wound. This can occur anywhere from three to 14 days after coming in contact with a cat. [1] X Trustworthy Source FamilyDoctor.org Family-focused medical advice site run by the American Academy of Family Doctors Go to source Visit a doctor if you believe that you have cat scratch fever.

steps.title: Observe any papule or pustules.
steps.content: Observe any papule or pustules. You may notice the growth of small blisters or lesions around the site of the wound. These open sores or pus-filled pimples are also indicative of an infection and will appear less than two weeks after contamination. [2] X Trustworthy Source FamilyDoctor.org Family-focused medical advice site run by the American Academy of Family Doctors Go to source Do not pop or burst the pustules. This may cause the spread of the infection.

steps.title: Look for swollen lymph nodes.
steps.content: Look for swollen lymph nodes. One to three weeks after exposure to B. henselae , your lymph nodes closest the infection site will be swollen and painful. These will be most common around the head, neck, and upper limbs. Look for small round bumps near the bite or scratch. [3] X Trustworthy Source FamilyDoctor.org Family-focused medical advice site run by the American Academy of Family Doctors Go to source

steps.title: Keep an eye out for fatigue.
steps.content: Keep an eye out for fatigue. If you are experiencing a cat scratch disease, you may become more tired than normal. You will generally feel tired, even after a restful night of sleep, and become fatigued more quickly while doing tasks. [4] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source Avoid over-exertion if you experience fatigue and be sure to get plenty of rest.

steps.title: Treat any headaches.
steps.content: Treat any headaches. Cat scratch disease can cause you to suffer from a headache, which will appear a few days after exposure. Use the recommended dosage of acetaminophen or other pain relievers to deal with headaches. [5] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Manage a low-grade fever.
steps.content: Manage a low-grade fever. A mild fever may also develop as a result of the infection. Your temperature will run somewhere between 99 and 101 degrees. Fever is a relatively common symptom of cat scratch disease, but not considered severe. Use pain relievers or fever reduces to manage the fever. Visit a doctor if your fever worsens.

steps.title: Observe severe muscle or joint pain.
steps.content: Observe severe muscle or joint pain. A very small number of those infected with cat scratch disease develop joint and muscle pain. Those reporting muscle and joint soreness tended to be under the age of 20. If untreated, this can result in chronic tendinitis, as well as persistent muscle and joint pain. [6] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source Contact your doctor if you experience and joint or muscle soreness associated cat scratch disease.

steps.title: Check for redness of eyes and blurred vision.
steps.content: Check for redness of eyes and blurred vision. In rare instances, cat scratch disease has been known to cause decreased vision and a limited visual field. [7] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Contact your doctor if you experience any difficultly seeing or changes in your vision. This tends to clear up with a dose of antibiotics.

steps.title: Look for lesions.
steps.content: Look for lesions. In people with compromised immune systems, B. henselae can cause bacillary angiomatosis, a disease characterized by lesions on the skin. This can present as sores in the skin, subcutaneous tissue, bone, or other organs. Lesions are particularly dangerous for people with compromised immune systems because they can increase the likelihood of infection. [8] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source This complication is most common among people with advanced HIV infection.

steps.title: Watch for neurological symptoms.
steps.content: Watch for neurological symptoms. You can develop encephalopathy (brain damage or malfunction), radiculopathy (local nerve injury), or ataxia (loss of muscle coordination) from cat scratch disease. Patients with and encephalopathy usually have confusion and disorientation. You may also have seizures or other neurological problems. [9] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source Most symptoms typically resolve after treatment, but some people are left with residual neurological defects from cat scratch fever.

steps.title: Check for blood in your urine.
steps.content: Check for blood in your urine. B. henselae can cause a bacillary peliosis, which is a vascular infection of the spleen or liver. If you have bacillary peliosis, you would have small blood in your urine, which might cause a darker discoloration. If untreated, this infection can result in a significant deterioration in health among those with compromised immune systems. [10] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source This complication is found almost exclusively among people with advanced HIV infection.

steps.title: Wash cat scratches and bites immediately.
steps.content: Wash cat scratches and bites immediately. If you are bitten or scratched by a cat, wash the wound with hot water and soap right away. This will wash away or kill any bacteria that may cause and infection. [11] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source You may also want to disinfect it and apply a bandage to further clean the wound and prevent and further infection.

steps.title: Clean hands after playing with cats.
steps.content: Clean hands after playing with cats. If you work with young children or people who have compromised immune systems, be sure to wash your hands after handling any cats. You may get B. henselae on your hands and transmit it to others through touch, especially if they have an open wound. [12] X Trustworthy Source FamilyDoctor.org Family-focused medical advice site run by the American Academy of Family Doctors Go to source Always wear gloves when working around people with open wounds or infectious diseases.

steps.title: Get cats older than one.
steps.content: Get cats older than one. Because young cats are more likely to carry the disease, people with compromised immune systems should get cats older than one. This will minimize the likelihood of an infection. [13] X Trustworthy Source FamilyDoctor.org Family-focused medical advice site run by the American Academy of Family Doctors Go to source Your local shelter or pet store should be able to help you find a cat that will work best for you.

steps.title: Play gently with cats.
steps.content: Play gently with cats. Rough housing with your cat increases the likelihood that they will bite or scratch you. Your cat may not know that you are playing and get agitated.

steps.title: Control fleas.
steps.content: Control fleas. Because B. henselae is transmitted from fleas to cats to humans, you can constrain the spread of cat scratch disease by limiting your cat's exposure to fleas. Apply a flea product to your cat and check its fur for fleas regularly. Also, keep your home flea-free by vacuuming regularly and contacting pest control if you notice any fleas. Some over the counter flea guards can be harmful to your cat. Consult your veterinarian before applying any product to your cat.

steps.title: Take your cat to the veterinarian.
steps.content: Take your cat to the veterinarian. You can also help ensure your cat's health by scheduling regular checkups with your vet. They can test for cat scratch disease and give you advice on how to limit your exposure to the disease.
